intro: Rhus gueinzii, commonly known as the Mexican sumac, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Anacardiaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like poison ivy and cashew. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves, which are often arranged in pairs along the stem. Its small, yellowish-green flowers are followed by red, fuzzy fruits that mature in the fall. Rhus gueinzii is adapted to a variety of soil types and is often found in woodland edges and disturbed areas.
